Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Quake-Catcher Network: Rapid Aftershock Mobilization Program (QCN RAMP)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This rapid response proposal will install 50 strong motion sensors to investigate the aftershock sequence resulting from the February 27, 2010 M 8.8 earthquake in Chile. Aftershock sequences are transitory, with the rate and magnitude of aftershocks decaying rapidly with time, requiring prompt deployment of instrumentation to capture the sequence. The PIs intend to use new computational techniques and lowcost MEMS sensors implemented by the Quake-Catcher Network to install 50 strong motion tri-axial accelerometers in the region.

The proposed work will benefit earthquake seismology and its application to rupture dynamics, strong ground motion generation, and near-source strong ground motion amplification effects. The data produced by this proposal may help enable us to determine how aftershocks interact with each other. The data may also help demonstrate if large aftershocks significantly differ from the main shock and/or each other in the rupture properties and slip distribution. The rupture occurred in the vicinity of the largest earthquake ever recorded (M9.5 on May 22, 1960), making this region particularly important to understanding earthquake rupture properties and aftershock distributions.

Additional benefit will result from testing this new technology in a rapid response scenario. If this experiment is successful, future experiments with ongoing improvements to sensors and our distributed computing network will allow for extremely dense and rapid aftershock deployments. Through the work proposed here we hope to better understand the limitations and benefits of using a distributed computing network for rapid aftershock investigations and investigate the feasibility of utilizing such a deployment for earthquake advanced alert in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Following the magnitude 8.8 earthquake in Maule, Chile in 2010 we dispatched two graduate students with 100 low-cost MEMS sensors to the damaged region in order to measure large aftershocks. The project was partially aimed at increasing data quantities, and partially aimed at testing this new technology in an aftershock scenario.  The new technologies performed very well, and we recorded many large magnitude earthquakes.  We used social networking to help find participants to host seismic sensors on their computers.  The computers monitor the sensors, and relay the data to the Quake-Catcher Network (QCN) servers at Stanford.  At Stanford we store and analyze the data.

As a result of this rapid aftershock mobilization program, we were able to develop software for rapid event detection, which includes identifying that an earthquake has occurred, locating the earthquake hypocenter, and estimating the earthquake's magnitude.  The locations and magnitudes agree well with estimates obtained by the USGS.  This research led to a publication in seismological research letters.  The ability to estimate location and magnitude are both important for both studying earthquakes and understanding the hazards that earthquakes pose. 

In addition we developed software to quickly convert small packets of data rapidly transmitted to the server into estimated shake maps.   These estimated shake maps illuminate regions with greater shaking intensity, which could be used in the future for identifying where first responders should focus their energies. This positive test of the QCN software and hardware illustrates the utility of such a network.  This is particularly true for countries that cannot (or will not) afford traditional (costly) sensor networks.

Using the knowledge gained from this experiment, we were able to implement a real-time earthquake detection algorithm for a rapid aftershock deployment following Darfield, magnitude 7.2 earthquake later that year.  We can now identify, locate, and estimate the rough magnitude of nearby earthquakes in a matter of seconds.

More information about the Quake-Catcher Network and our findings can be found at http://qcn.stanford.edu.  We encourage individuals, schools, and organizations to become involved in earthquake monitoring.  At our website, individuals can find educational material as well as forms to pre-register for rapid aftershock mobilization programs if a large earthquake should occur in their region.
